title: Is it a better idea for a financial advisor to get their own financial advisor or should they advise themselves? - Quora

response.answer_text: Oh yeah. An FA who manages his own account often does have a fool for a client. I have encountered few FAs that won’t concede, between friends, that their worst performing accounts are often their own. I suspect, again speaking from experience, that’s it’s some part a lack of accountability (“it’s not as though my spouse is going to fire me”), some part a tendency toward overconfidence (e.g. “the rules don’t apply to me”) and some part the sense that more risk will be rewarded with commensurate return. As it turns out, letting another FA manage your account can be a gratifying and educational experience. It’s always interesting to observe, at first hand, a different approach and different thinking. Better yet, you gain all sorts of unique insights into what the clients experience and how they react to advice in different circumstances. Good question. Hope this helps.
There are many analogies. What do doctors, accountants, etc. do? However the difference is that the advisor can be a DIY.
